Title: The 50 Best Christmas Movies, from ‚ÄòEyes Wide Shut‚Äô and ‚ÄòCarol‚Äô to ‚ÄòBatman Returns‚Äô and ‚ÄòChristmas Vacation‚Äô
URL: https://www.indiewire.com/gallery/christmas-movies-best-holiday-films/
Time Published: 2025-12-08T16:00:18Z
Full Content:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy. We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply. In the spirit of the magic of the season (and in hopes of providing some warm respite from the usual end-of-the-year best-of deluge of stories and their attendant doldrums), IndieWire is proud to present our first-ever Holiday Week. [Editor‚Äôs note: This list was originally published in December 2022. It has since been updated with new entries.] Rockin‚Äô around the Christmas tree at the Christmas movie stop! That‚Äôs right: You‚Äôve reached the North Pole of movie recommendations, where our toymakers (read: film critics) have been hard at work sifting through titles all year long. It‚Äôs easy to think of holiday movies as the one area of cinema audiences have permission to practically forget about the rest of the year. With a limited window between Thanksgiving and Christmas, most film lovers can only make time for a handful of seasonally appropriate screenings before New Year‚Äôs snaps our attention back to awards season and the big Best Picture contenders. Plus, with new yuletide offerings hitting theaters and streaming platforms in a steady flurry throughout December, there‚Äôs only so much time to enjoy Christmas classics while staying current on new holiday fare. Selection is made even more complex when you get into the Christmas genre‚Äôs inexplicable tendency toward gatekeeping. It‚Äôs a frustrating reality of the movie machine that some titles, for no real discernible reason, get saddled with debates that have relatively little to do with their stories. Such is the case with John McTiernan‚Äôs ‚ÄúDie Hard‚Äù: the 1988 action-packed crowdpleaser starring Bruce Willis that‚Äôs become synonymous with the contentious classification of so-called ‚ÄúChristmas movies‚Äù and the separately defined ‚Äúmovies set at Christmas.‚Äù In curating this list, we‚Äôve disregarded that delineation, allowing Stanley Kubrick‚Äôs psychosexual thriller ‚ÄúEyes Wide Shut‚Äù and Bob Clark‚Äôs slasher ‚ÄúBlack Christmas‚Äù their rightful spots alongside traditional TV specials, from ‚ÄúA Charlie Brown Christmas‚Äù to ‚ÄúRudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer.‚Äù The best Christmas movies, as defined here, make up a collection of films celebrating and/or challenging the holiday while using its motifs and themes to explore the light and dark sides of the human spirit. Selections have been ranked with both Christmas relevance and overall film quality in mind. Check out IndieWire‚Äôs guide to the best Thanksgiving movies. With editorial contributions by David Ehrlich, Jim Hemphill, Sarah Shachat, and Christian Zilko. You‚Äôd be hard-pressed to find a Disney fan willing to argue ‚ÄúBeauty and the Beast: The Enchanted Christmas‚Äù is ‚Äúbetter‚Äù than the original. But director Andy Knight‚Äôs straight-to-VHS release from 1997 ‚Äî a ‚Äúmidquel‚Äù imagining Belle and the Beast‚Äôs first Christmas, from before Gaston leads that angry mob to their castle in the first film ‚Äî is ridiculously magical. The story sees none other than Tim Curry give voice to the formidable Forte. A grumpy composer turned into an evil pipe organ by the witch‚Äôs curse, the hidden gem Disney villain doesn‚Äôt want the spell broken because he likes his new life. The late Paul Reubens voices Forte‚Äôs right-hand, Fife, a trembling piccolo willing to do anything for the solo his conductor has promised him if the Beast doesn‚Äôt become human. ‚ÄúEnchanted Christmas‚Äù makes heavy use of early CGI (Forte himself is entirely digital) and it lacks much of the hand-drawn charm that made the earlier masterpiece. But with Bernadette Peters adding even more holiday cheer ‚Äî she‚Äôs a tree angel and love interest for Lumiere (Jerry Orbach, again) ‚Äî this is the seed that planted the forest of holiday spin-offs Disney devotees continue to enjoy each year. ‚ÄîAF Netflix has attempted more than its fair share of Christmas movies, including Best Animated Feature nominee ‚ÄúKlaus‚Äù in 2019. But ‚ÄúJingle Jangle: A Christmas Journey‚Äù stands out from the streaming service‚Äôs crowd ‚Äî offering everything from a Dolly Parton musical to Kurt Russell as Santa ‚Äî with writer/director David Talbert‚Äôs delightfully overstuffed celebration of holiday excess. A blistering race through Christmas spectacle, musical bangers, top-notch acting, and maybe (read: definitely) one too many steampunk-inspired visual effects, ‚ÄúJingle Jangle‚Äù makes for a snow globe-like display akin to a modern spin on the chorus line musical extravaganzas of yesteryear. Originally envisioned as a stage production, the 2020 straight-to-streaming film follows Forest Whittaker‚Äôs inventor character as he bonds with his brilliant granddaughter, portrayed by Madalen Mills. Together, they pull off a harrowing rescue mission, unravel a dastardly plot, and find new hope in the holiday spirit. ‚ÄîAF For the only tie on this list, we offer up two adaptations of Dr. Seuss‚Äô ‚ÄúHow the Grinch Stole Christmas‚Äù (knowing full well there are at least two other features you could consider that don‚Äôt make the cut). The 1957 children‚Äôs story was adapted first by ‚ÄúLooney Tunes‚Äù artist Chuck Jones and his longtime collaborator Ben Washam in a brilliantly crafted animated special, which aired on CBS in December 1966. This version boasts Boris Karloff as the voice of the Grinch: a performance that would shape the humbug-turned-unlikely hero for decades to come. Channelling Karloff‚Äôs rendering and the curling physicality of Jones and Washam‚Äôs illustrative design, Jim Carrey totally embodies the fabled mean one in Ron Howard‚Äôs live-action outing from 2000. The aughts favorite is perhaps most celebrated for its quotable lines (‚ÄúAm I just eating because I‚Äôm bored?‚Äù) but is infamous for its intense prosthetics and costuming, which Carrey reportedly despised. Still, it earned three Oscar nominations and won for Best Makeup. ‚ÄîAF On par with ‚ÄúThe Music Box‚Äù and ‚ÄúWay Out West‚Äù as a matter of family fun, this Laurel and Hardy musical from 1934 adapts parts of Victor Herbert‚Äôs 1903 stage production for a fantastic fairytale adventure revolving around a home mortgage dispute (yes, really). When a traveling salesman (the late Hoyt Axton) brings home a strange new pet for his son, known as a ‚Äúmogwai,‚Äù hero Billy Peltzer (Zach Gilligan) is tasked with abiding by three rules of care: no sunlight, no water, and no feeding it after midnight. Naturally, it takes no time at all for Billy to screw up and unleash the consequences of his adorable Christmas present on his unsuspecting town. ‚ÄúGremlins‚Äù qualifies as top holiday viewing not only because its zany antics take place at Christmas, but because it also includes one of the most baffling beats in ‚ÄúHome Alone‚Äù director Chris Columbus‚Äô screenwriting history. Truly, Phoebe Cates‚Äô infamous Santa-in-a-chimney monologue is one tonal mystery that keeps on giving. ‚ÄîAF What do NYPD detective John McClane and classic holiday singer Bing Crosby have in common? They‚Äôll both be home for Christmas. John McTiernan‚Äôs ‚ÄúDie Hard‚Äù chronicles the ill-fated reunion of Bruce Willis‚Äô starring action hero and his estranged wife Holly (Bonnie Bedelia) at her company‚Äôs Christmas party in Los Angeles. McClane‚Äôs plans to win his wife back come undone when a high-stakes heist disguised as a terrorist attack takes over the festivities thanks to Alan Rickman‚Äôs notorious villain Hans Gruber. At its core, ‚ÄúDie Hard‚Äù is a tale of redemption. Sure, he‚Äôs not as on-the-nose naughty as the Grinch or Scrooge, but McClane is paying for past mistakes through the hellish ordeal that unfolds before/beneath/beside/above him in an explosive act of absolution. Even more memorable is the story of Al Powell (Reginald VelJohnson), an LAPD officer whose history on the force motivates the film‚Äôs heroic climax. If that worthy Christmas message isn‚Äôt reason enough for you to check it out, then trust that the script is full of holiday gems: from saccharine platitudes (‚ÄúIt‚Äôs Christmas, Theo! It‚Äôs the time of miracles‚Ä¶‚Äù) to season‚Äôs greetings (‚ÄúYippee-ki-yay, motherfuckers!‚Äù) ‚ÄîAF Bob Clark‚Äôs ‚ÄúA Christmas Story‚Äù has a rhythmic familiarity for some families: celebrated each year in an all-day marathon on TBS, seamlessly looping from Ralphie‚Äôs initial request for a Red Ryder carbine-action BB gun (that‚Äôs the ‚Äú200-shot, range model air rifle with a compass in the stock and this thing that tells time,‚Äù of course) to the warm glow of Christmas morning when he discovers whether or not his dream present made it in under the tree. Along the way, Jean Shepherd, who co-wrote the script with Clark and Leigh Brown (not to mention narrates as an older Ralphie), imbues the Parker family with details from his real life, first appearing in his short stories. The road-weary marriage of Melinda Dillon and Darren McGavin‚Äôs Mrs. and Mr. Parker stands out as a testament to parents pushing to their absolute limits to make Christmas miracles. ‚ÄîAF Not to be confused with its 1994 remake (though the Mara Wilson vehicle does have its moments), 1947‚Äôs ‚ÄúMiracle on 34th Street‚Äù is the masterwork of writer/director George Seaton that continues to shape how New Yorkers honor the holidays. The black-and-white film stars Edmund Gwenn as Kris Kringle: the new Santa at a Macy‚Äôs department store who shocks the city when he claims to be the real Saint Nick. An 8-year-old Natalie Wood plays Susan: a little girl whose faith in Kringle becomes central to the fairytale‚Äôs message. ‚ÄúMiracle on 34th Street‚Äù was nominated in multiple categories at that year‚Äôs Oscars, including Best Picture. It won three: two for writing and one for Gwenn, who clinched Best Supporting Actor. ‚ÄîAF There are two film adaptations of Charles Dickens‚Äô ‚ÄúA Christmas Carol‚Äù appearing on this list, with many, many more available. And though Brian Henson‚Äôs 1992 family favorite ranks lower than its competition, we can confidently say it‚Äôs got the better puppets. With Kermit the Frog (performed by Steve Whitmire) as its Bob Cratchit and Michael Caine playing Ebenezer Scrooge, ‚ÄúThe Muppet Christmas Carol‚Äù stays remarkably close to its Gothic source material: a smart grounding move that heightens the film‚Äôs bursts of Muppet parody to among the funniest in the ongoing franchise. Come for the promise of punny characters (Fozziewig!) and catchy musical numbers (‚ÄúIt feels like Chriiistmaaas!‚Äù). Stay for the goofy witticisms only the Muppets can do justice: ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a little absent-minded, spirit.‚Äù ‚ÄúNo, I‚Äôm a large absent-minded spirit!‚Äù ‚ÄîAF The holidays are a time of joy, but they‚Äôre also bittersweet. ‚ÄúThe Apartment‚Äù is one of the great melancholy Christmas films, a movie about being lonely and blue during that confusing period between Christmas and New Year‚Äôs. Jack Lemmon stars as meek office drone Baxter, who uses his bachelor pad to get ahead in his career by loaning it out as an affair spot for his married superiors. But when his office crush, elevator operator Fran (Shirley MacLaine, luminous), engages in an affair with the head of the company, he‚Äôs forced to reconsider the morals of what he‚Äôs doing, and what he really wants out of his life. It‚Äôs not the most cheery Christmas film of all time, but its perfectly awkward office holiday party scene and running joke about sending a fruitcake to a person whose heart you broke every December 25 firmly establish it in the sad Christmas canon. ‚ÄîWC The swan song of legendary Swedish auteur Ingmar Bergman, ‚ÄúFanny and Alexander‚Äù is an epic in miniature, capturing the lives of two young children born to a wealthy family as they contend with death and abuse but find comfort in themselves and their large extended family. The film, which in its uncut form runs over five hours long, begins with an extended act showcasing the decadent celebrations of the Ekdahl family across Christmas ‚Äî a relatively secular tradition in which even the Jewish uncle Isak is allowed to partake. The warmth and joy on display (it‚Äôs one of the most gorgeous Christmas parties in film history) make the rest of the film ‚Äî where the siblings‚Äô father dies, and their mother remarries to a severe and abusive Protestant bishop ‚Äî all the more stark in their cold isolation. Through the contrast between these two methods of religious celebration, ‚ÄúFanny and Alexander‚Äù is one of the few Christmas films to seriously contend with the religion of Christianity itself, asking questions about the role spirituality plays in our lives, and whether it can lead one to happiness or ruin. ‚ÄîWC Its sunny yellow Miami lighting doesn‚Äôt scream Christmas. But ‚ÄúTangerine,‚Äù Sean Baker‚Äôs breakout film, is very much of the season, taking place entirely on Christmas Eve. The madcap dramedy stars Kitana Kiki Rodriguez as Sin-Dee, a sex worker released from a short jail stint who discovers her boyfriend has been cheating on her. Enraged, she recruits her fellow prostitute and friend Alexandra (Mya Taylor) to help her find him. The film largely focuses on the two engaging in some very non-Christmas activities, from screaming fights to smoking meth. But their sweet friendship and almost sisterly bond keep the film of the season: if the holidays are about family, then the found family relationship seen in ‚ÄúTangerine‚Äù is one of the best. ‚ÄîWC Satoshi Kon is best known for his mind-bending, meta films like ‚ÄúPaprika‚Äù or ‚ÄúPerfect Blue,‚Äù movies that toy with ideas of self-perception, delusion, and identity. But between those enigmatic releases, he dropped ‚ÄúTokyo Godfathers,‚Äù a bittersweet tragicomedy Christmas film rooted in the down-and-out lives of ordinary people in modern-day Japan. The result is still one of the most offbeat and unusual Christmas films ever made, and also one of the most heartwarming. Heavily inspired by John Ford‚Äôs 1948 Western ‚Äú3 Godfathers,‚Äù ‚ÄúTokyo Godfathers‚Äù moves that story of gunslingers attempting to shepherd a baby to safety to Tokyo, where our heroes are three homeless people who find an abandoned child in the trash on Christmas Eve. Their journey across the city to find the kid‚Äôs parents is difficult and alternates between hilarious and sobering, but there‚Äôs an affection for these unlikely heroes that shines through the jokes. It‚Äôs a lovely look at the unluckiest of people during the season of giving. ‚ÄîWC For even some readers who first encountered the ghostly tale of Ebeneezer Scrooge on the page, the late Scottish actor Alastair Sim is the face of literature‚Äôs most famed redemptive protagonist. Directed by Brian Desmond Hurst, this 1951 black-and-white adaptation of ‚ÄúA Christmas Carol‚Äù ‚Äî also known as ‚ÄúScrooge‚Äù ‚Äî enjoys an otherworldly quality emanating from its now-antiquated filmmaking and Dickens‚Äô illustrious prose: exploring the supernatural side to Christmas in a winding story of a greedy businessman confronting his misdeeds via poltergeist. Sim‚Äôs turn as Scrooge sees the seasoned actor dexterously scale the philosophical work‚Äôs Jacob‚Äôs ladder, guiding the unlikely hero from a horror-esque villain to a soft-smiled man making peace with his life. He‚Äôd lead Guy Hamilton‚Äôs ‚ÄúAn Inspector Calls‚Äù as the titular inspector calling just two years later, in 1954. ‚ÄîAF Will Ferrell brings the Christmas spirit and then some in Jon Favreau‚Äôs fish-out-of-water (elf-out-of-snow?) 2003 comedy about an effervescent Christmas enthusiast visiting gritty New York City. After spending his entire life with Santa in the North Pole, Buddy the Elf arrives in Manhattan like a breath of syrup/candy/spaghetti-infused air: challenging his nasty Scrooge of an estranged father (the late James Caan) to accept his seemingly boundless love and affection. From picking out an ill-conceived gift for that ‚Äúspecial someone‚Äù to cutting down a tree in Central Park (a serious and illegal whoopsie!), ‚ÄúElf‚Äù is chockfull of familiar traditions twisted to their most misguided and extreme. It‚Äôs a crowdpleaser not just for fans of Ferrell and kids who grew up in the aughts, but anyone needing a reason to enjoy the season. After all, say it with me: ‚ÄúThe best way to spread Christmas cheer is singing loud for all to hear.‚Äù ‚ÄîAF ‚ÄúHave Yourself a Merry Little Christmas‚Äù is often used and recorded as a light, jubilant, or romantic song. But the iconic standard, as introduced by a sprightly Judy Garland in ‚ÄúMeet Me in St. Louis,‚Äù is actually a massive downer, a desperate attempt at comfort and happiness during a loved one‚Äôs darkest hour. Garland, whose rich voice has never been more beautiful, performs the song in the technicolor Vincente Minnelli musical as hopeless romantic Esther to her little sister Tootie (Margaret O‚ÄôBrien) after they discover their father will be moving the whole family away from their home. It‚Äôs meant to comfort Tootie, but also herself, as she will be ripped away from the boy she loves right after he proposed to her. The scene on Christmas Eve is the only part of ‚ÄúMeet Me in St. Louis‚Äù that actually focuses on the holidays, but its perfect blend of melancholy and beauty makes the film an essential entry in the Christmas canon. ‚ÄîWC Cate Blanchett and Rooney Mara will knock the breath from your chest in Todd Haynes‚Äô ‚ÄúCarol.‚Äù Adapted for the screen by Phyllis Nagy, from Patricia Highsmith‚Äôs 1952 ‚ÄúThe Price of Salt,‚Äù this lesbian period romance (a subgenre done to death, we know) chronicles the swelling attraction between the shop girl/aspiring photographer Therese Belivet and the magnetic soon-to-be divorcee Carol Aird. At first blush, one might clump the women‚Äôs love story ‚Äî featuring clandestine looks framed in artificial snow and an understated meet-cute involving a Santa hat ‚Äî with other seasonal romances, such as ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve Got Mail‚Äù or ‚ÄúLove Actually‚Äù (also appearing on this list). But where those romantic comedies cut their lovers‚Äô budding tension with holiday antics, ‚ÄúCarol‚Äù dares to stare deep into the melancholy thoughtfulness that comes with this time of year by incorporating a heart-rending story of a gay woman fighting to be with her daughter. The result gifts romance fans a slow-burn consideration of the bold futures we choose to allow ourselves and a final shot that will make your heart grow three sizes. ‚ÄîAF It‚Äôd be a little cliched to crown director Frank Capra‚Äôs ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a Wonderful Life‚Äù the best Christmas movie of all time: what with the seemingly endless references and homages to it appearing in other holiday films. And yet, to deny hero George Bailey‚Äôs all-time heartbreaker one of the top spots feels just about as nice list-qualifying as denying Santa his cookies. Plus, who really needs to justify giving a James Stewart performance ‚Äî arguably, his best (though the legendary actor would only win an Oscar for 1940‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Philadelphia Story‚Äù) ‚Äî supreme accolades? Based on Philip Van Doren Stern‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Greatest Gift,‚Äù this 1946 black-and-white fable considers the melancholia and existential despair characteristic for so many at the holidays. When news of a man‚Äôs suicidal thoughts reach heaven, Henry Travers‚Äô guardian angel character Clarence Odbody intervenes. For those with a heavy heart this time of year ‚Äî or any for that matter ‚Äî ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a Wonderful Life‚Äù offers a hopeful salve from an old world. ‚ÄîAF It takes a special kind of balding, depressed, zig-zag-wearing kid to anchor not one, not two, but three major holiday specials. Four if you count ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the Great Pumpkin, Charlie Brown,‚Äù ‚ÄúA Charlie Brown Thanksgiving,‚Äù ‚ÄúA Charlie Brown Christmas,‚Äù and ‚ÄúA Charlie Brown Valentine‚Äù (though that last one might be on the fringes of modern popularity and there are other lesser titles we‚Äôre not mentioning). After Lucy asks Charlie Brown to direct the Christmas play, he‚Äôs thrust into a challenging leadership position that sees him battling Schroeder‚Äôs piano and the rest of the gang‚Äôs antics for attention. Simultaneously, Linus considers the biblical origins of the holiday and ponders what we owe to one another. The best friends‚Äô journeys meet at night in a cold lot, where Charlie Brown picks out what may very well be the most instantly recognizable Christmas tree in TV and film history. ‚ÄîAF Stanley Kubrick‚Äôs final movie is unlike any other of the holly-jolly titles on this list, but there‚Äôs no denying the late filmmaker had something to say about Christmas with his sordid tale of a husband and wife‚Äôs thorny encounter with an underground sex cult. Finished just days before Kubrick‚Äôs death, ‚ÄúEyes Wide Shut‚Äù stars Nicole Kidman and Tom Cruise as a raw nerve of a couple whose growing resentment culminates in a would-be affair spun out of control. Tinsel and lights offer an obvious (and ominously gorgeous) seasonal background for the film, released in July 1999. But it‚Äôs Kubrick‚Äôs repeated presentation of the holiday‚Äôs innate consumerism that drives home his thesis ‚Äî or at least one interpretation of a thesis! ‚Äî that marriages and families can be hungrily consumed by the vapid mundanity of self-obsession and competitive capitalism. ‚ÄîAF Not just one of the greatest Christmas rom-coms, but one of the greatest rom-coms period, ‚ÄúThe Shop Around the Corner‚Äù and its tale of pen pals falling in love during the Christmas season has been adapted and modernized several times, such as in the Broadway musical ‚ÄúShe Loves Me‚Äù or ‚Äô90s email film ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve Got Mail.‚Äù But Ernst Lubitsch‚Äôs original, based on the play ‚ÄúParfumerie,‚Äù remains the greatest telling. In the Budapest leathergoods shop where they work, Klara (Margaret Sullavan) and Alfred (James Stewart) bicker endlessly, but in the anonymous letters they write to each other, they both reveal their softer sides and find themselves smitten with the stranger they don‚Äôt know. Both actors are phenomenal, with beautiful simple chemistry that‚Äôs alternatively spiky and sweet. They‚Äôre supported by a lovely cast, including Frank Morgan as the owner of the store Matuschek who discovers his wife is having an affair. What makes the film such a holiday great is its exploration of lonlieness during the winter months, from the two leads struggling to find love to Matuschek‚Äôs despair over his situation. It‚Äôs a simple but moving story about finding connection, and how love and companionship can be the greatest gift of all. ‚ÄîWC By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy. Title: AST SpaceMobile Aims to Launch FM2, Its Second Prototype Satellite, in January
URL: https://uk.pcmag.com/wireless-carriers/161905/ast-spacemobile-aims-to-launch-fm2-its-second-prototype-satellite-in-january
Time Published: 2025-12-08T15:51:40Z
Full Content:
PCMag editors select and review products independently. If you buy through affiliate links, we may earn commissions, which help support our testing. Our team tests, rates, and reviews more than 1,500 products each year to help you make better buying decisions and get more from technology. AST SpaceMobile is hoping to launch a second next-generation prototype satellite "as early as January" as it races to compete with SpaceX‚Äôs cellular Starlink service. The company disclosed the launch timing in a new Federal Communications Commission filing. AST is already on track to launch its first prototype satellite, FM1, later this month. However, it appears that it's also scrambling to launch the FM2 as soon as possible. ‚ÄúAs part of its proactive efforts to secure sufficient launches for its satellite constellation on an expedited basis, AST SpaceMobile was able to secure an accelerated launch slot capable of launching a BlueBird satellite as early as January 2026,‚Äù the company wrote. Interestingly, AST has tapped rival SpaceX to launch the satellite using a Falcon 9 rocket. But the filing notes: ‚ÄúIn order to meet quick turnaround launch requirements, AST SpaceMobile was constrained in the available orbital parameters for launch. The alternative was to forgo the launch opportunity.‚Äù The company secured FCC clearance in August to fly up the FM2. However, the "constrained" orbit parameters are leading AST to request regulatory permission to launch the FM2 satellite at a lower orbit, from 520 kilometers down to 460 kilometers. AST describes the lower orbit as part of ‚Äúa few minor changes‚Äù that won‚Äôt lead to increased radio interference. ‚ÄúGrant of this application will serve the public interest by facilitating expeditious deployment of a new, groundbreaking space-based cellular network that will deliver direct-to-device broadband connectivity across the United States,‚Äù the company added. Still, the company‚Äôs application might face opposition from rival companies, such as SpaceX. It could also take time for the FCC to review and clear the application, although the Commission has been working to fast-track satellite approvals. AST‚Äôs first prototype, the FM1, is currently scheduled to launch on Dec. 15. The company has tapped India‚Äôs space agency to launch the satellite, which is about three times larger than AST's first-generation BlueBirds. The square-shaped satellites have been designed to act as cell towers in space, capable of powering high-speed broadband to phones on the ground. The goal is to operate 45 to 60 BlueBird satellites by the end of next year‚Äîenough for the company to provide continuous coverage through partners such as AT&T and Verizon. In addition, ‚ÄúAST SpaceMobile expects five orbital launches by the end of Q1 2026, with launches occurring every one to two months on average,‚Äù the company told the FCC. Hence, the launch timing is crucial when AST faces heightened competition from SpaceX. The company's own cellular Starlink system launched through T-Mobile earlier this year, and can already power text messaging, app data, and even video calls for phones in cellular dead zones. Now SpaceX is preparing to bulk up the system‚Äôs capabilities after acquiring valuable radio spectrum from Boost Mobile‚Äôs parent, EchoStar. Elon Musk's company has even gone as far as to file the trademark for ‚ÄúStarlink Mobile,‚Äù suggesting SpaceX might try to become a global carrier, but primarily through satellites. Title: Yep, Xbox Is Bleeding Out
URL: https://gizmodo.com/xbox-is-bleeding-out-black-friday-2025-sales-2000696718
Time Published: 2025-12-08T15:33:20Z
Full Content:

Title: Invesco Teams Up With LGT on Private Equity and Credit for Retail
URL: https://www.wealthmanagement.com/alternative-investments/invesco-teams-up-with-lgt-on-private-equity-and-credit-for-retail
Time Published: 2025-12-08T15:19:35Z
Full Content:
It‚Äôs at least the second partnership Invesco has struck since late April, when it joined with Barings on private credit funds. December 8, 2025 (Bloomberg) --Invesco Ltd. is taking another step to expand its presence in private markets, teaming up with LGT Capital Partners on portfolios of alternative assets for US retail and retirement investors. The plan will cover private equity, credit and infrastructure assets as well investments in the market for secondary stakes, the firms said Monday in a statement. It‚Äôs at least the second partnership Invesco has struck since late April, when the Atlanta-based firm that manages $2.1 trillion of client assets joined with Barings on private credit funds. ‚ÄúPrivate markets exposure can provide differentiated sources of income and growth,‚Äù Invesco Chief Executive Officer Andrew Schlossberg said in the statement. Read More: Invesco, Barings to Offer Private Credit to Everyday Clients Traditional managers of stocks and bonds have moved aggressively into alternative markets during the past year, buying boutique firms or striking joint ventures to sell private assets to everyday investors. Blackstone Inc. is teaming up with Vanguard Group and Wellington Management Co., Apollo Global Management Inc. partnered with State Street Corp., and Capital Group is working with KKR & Co. Meanwhile, BlackRock Inc. spent about $25 billion to acquire Global Infrastructure Partners and HPS Investment Partners. Related:RIA Cerity Takes Stake in Secondary Private Markets Firm Invesco, best known for its QQQ equity funds tracking Nasdaq stocks, has more than $190 billion of alternative assets largely in real estate and private debt. It‚Äôs also a major manager of stable value funds common in retirement accounts, a type of product that could wind up allocating to private credit. LGT, with about $120 billion of assets, is owned by the Princely Family of Liechtenstein. ‚ÄúThe alliance marks a significant step in strengthening our presence in the US market, expanding our wealth management capabilities, and exploring opportunities in the retirement space,‚Äù Roberto Paganoni, LGT‚Äôs CEO, said in the statement. Title: AI Might Be Coming for Your Job. There‚Äôs a Proven Way to Prevent That.
URL: https://www.esquire.com/lifestyle/money/a69620765/midlife-career-change-entrepreneuralism/
Time Published: 2025-12-08T15:00:00Z
Full Content:
More middle-age and older Americans are becoming entrepreneurs and seizing control of their careers. The leap can be stressful but ultimately rewarding‚Äîjust listen to the people who‚Äôve already done it. If the rise of artificial intelligence has you feeling anxious about your professional future, you‚Äôre not alone. It seems that every day there‚Äôs another article painting a doomsday scenario for the white-collar, professional worker, whose job will be transformed or eliminated in this career apocalypse. A recent Wall Street Journal story made this loud and clear with the headline ‚ÄúWalmart CEO Issues Wake-Up Call: AI Is Going to Change Literally Every Job.‚Äù The story‚Äôs message: AI will wipe out some jobs and reshape the company‚Äôs workforce. The article included a quote from Accenture CEO Julie Sweet, who said the firm is ‚Äúexiting‚Äù employees who can‚Äôt be retrained for the AI age. Meanwhile, Accenture will continue to hire people who are fluent in generative AI and retrain existing workers to serve clients in consulting and other divisions. It strikes me that the veiled reference to exiting employees meant those over the age of 50. It gave me d√©j√† vu of when business leaders said the same thing at the dawn of the digital age. It‚Äôs ironic that many of the C-suite leaders making such proclamations are themselves older than 50 and have no real tangible experience with AI. During the digital shift, the rush to hire ‚Äúdigiterati‚Äù 20-somethings kicked in at full gear. Ultimately, businesses learned younger employees weren‚Äôt the cure-all for their digital strategies, as more seasoned employees with years of experience figured out how to evolve business models into the digital age. As a publishing executive who had to navigate the print-to-digital transformation, I was easily ‚Äúretrained‚Äù in my 50s, as were many of my colleagues. As for the companies hiring people who are supposedly fluent in AI, it‚Äôs too early in the artificial-intelligence game. No one of any age has accumulated enough knowledge or experience to be true AI natives. But I‚Äôm putting my money on older employees who helped navigate the digital age and ultimately became experts. For people in their 50s, corporate careers can be treacherous waters, complete with ‚Äúdownsizing‚Äù and ‚Äúrightsizing,‚Äù reorganizations, budget cuts, divisional closures, mergers and acquisitions, the cost of senior talent, and the antiquated idea of mandatory retirement that still exists in certain professions. Now add the glaring headlines that companies like Target, Amazon, Salesforce, IBM, and others are announcing layoffs, many due to the integration of AI into their businesses, resulting in what they say is the need for fewer employees. In other words, the corporate waters seem more treacherous than ever‚Äîbut there is a proven way to take control of your career before someone else does it for you. If you are in mid-career, now may be the time to rethink your future. It might also be the moment to embrace your inner entrepreneur. According to a 2019 study by the Ewing Marion Kauffman Foundation, nearly 25 percent of new entrepreneurs were between 55 and 64, almost double from 20 years prior. A 2018 research report from Pierre Azoulay, Ph.D., a professor at the MIT Sloan School of Management, found that the average age of a successful start-up founder is 45 and that a 50-year-old founder is 1.8 times as likely to have a hit company as people in other age groups. It makes sense. By 50, you‚Äôve likely amassed expertise, industry knowledge, meaningful contacts, and either your own financial resources or access to investment dollars based on your background. There‚Äôs not only a growing body of research on midlife entrepreneurialism but also books and real-life examples to serve as a road map. Kerry Hannon, for instance, is an entrepreneur focused on career and retirement strategies; she‚Äôs also a speaker and author of several books for those at midlife thinking of making a change. Her book Never Too Old to Get Rich: The Entrepreneur‚Äôs Guide to Starting a Business Mid-Life is a meaningful playbook, as is Lynne Beverly Strang‚Äôs Late-Blooming Entrepreneurs: Eight Principles for Starting a Business After Age 40. A key lesson from these experts is to have a well-thought-out idea that may be an extension of what you‚Äôve done for a living, a new dimension to your background, or an entirely fresh entrepreneurial idea. Matthew Grzybowski, a Polish-born American with a master‚Äôs degree in international business who spent nearly two decades in consulting and working for a wealthy European family office, is a prime example of the midlife entrepreneur spirit. When his wife, Veronica, took a sabbatical from her job as a Polish-Korean translator and discovered her love of dog training, it sparked an idea for both of them. As residents of Southampton, New York, they saw a need for a holistic approach to dog care that included daycare, boarding, training, and the requisite spa with bath, blow-dry, brush, and haircut. All their guests get individual walks and playtime, as they relax in the 17 cabanas for the pups. After two years of planning and the decision to self-fund, Southampton Dog opened in late 2024. The business is already profitable, according to the owners. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a place where dogs learn and people connect,‚Äù explained Grzybowski, who's pictured at the top of this story. ‚ÄúWe have local firefighters and front-page celebrities who are our clients, and we all bond over the dogs.‚Äù The cheery 10,000-square-foot facility is the first of what Matthew and Veronica hope will expand to at least three more locations in the next few years. My friend Steve is another excellent example of an entrepreneur in the making. After earning his M.B.A. at UCLA, he worked in entertainment, media, and data-analytics companies. At the age of 51, he was laid off when his company went through yet another reorganization. Ironically, his last assignment was building an AI-strategy road map for his division. At 52, Steve decided he was done with the corporate world, but he still had years of work ahead of him and decided to take the entrepreneurial path. He signed up for the eight-week MIT online course ‚ÄúLeadership in the AI Age: Driving digital transformation for competitive advantage.‚Äù His goal is to lean into his years of business experience, adding his new AI knowledge into a practice that advises C-suite executives on ways to adopt AI into their companies, including retraining all their employees, regardless of their age. These stories help to animate a major trend in America, where 21 percent of the population is over 55. According to SCORE, a resource partner of the Small Business Administration, 50.9 percent of small businesses are owned by this group. John Melia, the founder and executive director of the Wounded Warrior Project, who also had a long career in both the nonprofit and for-profit space, became an entrepreneur in his late 50s, launching Contender Equipment Rentals, a veteran-owned construction-equipment-rental company in Texas. ‚ÄúI felt called to build something new from the ground up,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThe idea came from my time in the oil and gas company, where I worked in telematics and sold to rental companies. I realized I had the mindset, the drive, and the operational understanding to start a company of my own.‚Äù His advice to anyone over 50 thinking of launching a business is to do it‚Äîbut do it wisely. Life experience, emotional intelligence, and a strong filter for what matters are important ingredients for success, according to Melia. As life expectancies grow, the idea of retiring at 65 is becoming an outdated concept. If you are that age and healthy, you may live another 30 years. It‚Äôs the perfect time to realize that entrepreneurialism has no real age limitations. Luciano Bernardini de Pace had a long career selling advertising in Milan (including for this magazine). In his late 60s, he returned to his hometown in the Puglia region of Italy. There he started an Italian pasta company called Luciano.Market, tapping his media background to spread the word digitally, including videos on YouTube and TikTok. He also restored a palazzo in Bagnolo del Salento, renamed Palazzo Bernardini de Pace, a luxury mansion that he has turned into a boutique hotel. According to Bernardini de Pace, he never really thought about his age. He had an idea that he was passionate about and took the risk. For David Harrison, it was his age that led him to entrepreneurism. As a United Airlines international first officer pilot on the 787 Dreamliner, he is required to retire at 65. His entrepreneurial leap has been to go back to school to earn a master‚Äôs degree in wealth management at Columbia University‚Äôs School for Professional Studies. It‚Äôs a 16-month asynchronous program with two residencies, ideal for his globe-trotting schedule. His pivot will be to support his community, family, and friends as a wealth advisor. ‚ÄúI want to be able to help people achieve their life goals, not just their financial goals,‚Äù he said. According to the Wall Street Journal story ‚ÄúThe New Age of Entrepreneurship: 70 to 79,‚Äù the entrepreneurial urge doesn‚Äôt necessarily diminish with age. The article included a profile of 71-year-old Judson Vaughn, who partnered with a 77-year-old to create online courses to teach lawyers how to be entertaining as well as effective. Alan Patricof is perhaps the ultimate role model for a late-in-life renaissance. A seasoned Wall Street executive and investor philanthropist, he has been a serial entrepreneur his whole adult life. In his early 80s, he founded Primetime Partners with Abby Levy. In his mid-80s, he became a first-time author, writing No Red Light about his career in venture capital and more. At 88, he was the oldest participant in the New York City Marathon in 2022. A year later, he got remarried. Becoming an entrepreneur at midlife can be both exhilarating and challenging, but for most who have taken the leap, they often ask, ‚ÄúWhat took me so long?‚Äù If the AI revolution is coming after your job, now might be the time to get ahead of it with your own entrepreneurial idea. And yes, you may have to integrate AI into your own business, but there is a big distinction. At least you‚Äôll own your company and never have to worry about that meeting with your boss when you enter the room and the human-resources person is sitting there too. Michael Clinton is the Founder of ROARforward.com and the author of ROAR into the second half of your life. Title: Stores Beat Robots As Kroger Opts For $350 Million Ocado Pay Off
URL: https://www.forbes.com/sites/markfaithfull/2025/12/08/stores-beat-robots-as-kroger-opts-for-350-million-ocado-pay-off/
Time Published: 2025-12-08T12:11:16Z
Full Content:
ByMark Faithfull, Contributor. Maybe the robots aren‚Äôt coming for us after all, as grocery retailer Kroger confirmed its retreat from its once-ambitious partnership with fulfillment specialist Ocado. The decision may have delivered a windfall to the U.K. automation specialist but underscores mounting pressures facing the largest traditional grocer in the U.S. as it rethinks how best to serve online customers. Ocado will receive a one-time payment of $350 million from Kroger after the chain decided to shutter three of its automated customer fulfillment centers and curb plans for a broader nationwide rollout. The payout, more generous than initially disclosed, draws a line under a strategy once slated to redefine Kroger‚Äôs e-commerce footprint but which has instead become an expensive detour. Kroger disclosed the closures last month as part of a sweeping operational review that revealed its Ocado-powered warehouse network was consistently falling short of internal financial targets. The company said it would book a $2.6 billion impairment, related largely to its new online strategy and asset writedowns at the automated sites. While the grocer emphasized it remains committed to digital growth, the adjustment amounts to an acknowledgment that a system designed to centralize order fulfillment in large, highly automated hubs has not scaled as intended. Instead, Kroger is pivoting back toward fulfilling a greater share of online orders from its extensive store estate, which covers more than 2,700 locations across 35 states. Ocado said Friday that it will continue to operate five active fulfillment centers for Kroger, while a sixth facility in Phoenix is still scheduled to open next year. But a planned site in Charlotte, North Carolina, has been scrapped entirely. The payment, which includes $250 million previously announced, will be made in January and is intended to settle obligations related to the canceled facilities and recalibrate the long-term economics of the partnership. For its part, Ocado reaffirmed its target of turning cash-flow positive in its 2026 fiscal year, insisting it will pursue that goal through a combination of international growth and tighter cost controls. The news prompted a stock price spike for Ocado before it dropped away again, leaving its shares down over 40% on the year. The shift marks a sharp reversal for a partnership that launched in 2018 with the ambition of building up to 20 automated hubs. At the time, Kroger described Ocado‚Äôs robotics and routing systems as an opportunity to leapfrog rivals in e-commerce. Early tests appeared promising, but volumes have remained stubbornly below projections, particularly in regions where Kroger‚Äôs market share is thinner and where consumer adoption of delivery remains uneven. The economics of large, automated warehouses in the U.S. have struggled to compete with the speed and density advantages of store-based fulfillment, especially as customers have gravitated toward pickup services. The strategic reversal comes as Kroger faces an increasingly complex landscape. The company is navigating a still-uncertain consumer environment marked by persistent inflation in key food categories, heightened price sensitivity and intensifying competition from Walmart, Costco and Amazon. Kroger‚Äôs most recent quarterly results showed modest total sales growth but shrinking operating margins, reflecting both promotional pressure and rising labor and logistics costs. The company ended its last fiscal year with roughly $19 billion of long-term debt and has been working to preserve cash ahead of its proposed merger with Albertsons, which remains under regulatory scrutiny. Kroger‚Äôs decision to unwind a portion of the Ocado build-out allows it to redirect capital toward areas that offer more predictable returns, including store remodels, private-label expansion and digital loyalty initiatives. For Ocado, Kroger represented the company‚Äôs most important international contract, both for scale and for proof-of-concept in the world‚Äôs largest grocery market. The recalibration inevitably raises questions about whether Ocado‚Äôs capital-intensive technology can justify its cost outside the densest urban areas. Ocado‚Äôs leadership has maintained that the U.S. still represents meaningful growth potential and that the exclusivity arrangement with Kroger has not prevented it from continuing discussions with other retailers for future opportunities. Yet the Kroger pullback adds to a string of setbacks. In the U.K., Morrisons said last year it would reduce its reliance on Ocado‚Äôs centralized warehouses and shift more online fulfillment back to its stores, using Ocado‚Äôs in-store picking software rather than the full automation suite. Other global partners, including Aeon in Japan, Casino in France, Coles in Australia and Sobeys in Canada, continue to build out Ocado-powered facilities, but none offers the scale or symbolic significance that a full U.S. rollout would have provided. In the U.S., Ocado‚Äôs challenges have been amplified by a market that is fragmented, logistically complex and increasingly dominated by retailers with vertically integrated fulfillment networks. Amazon continues to invest heavily in same-day nodes that are tightly aligned with its Whole Foods and Amazon Fresh operations, despite ongoing issues in the grocery market. Meantime, Walmart has leaned on its vast store base to create a hybrid fulfillment model that has proved both flexible and cost-effective. For Kroger, the priority now is stabilizing its digital economics. While online grocery sales for the company have grown significantly over recent years, profitability remains elusive. The grocer believes that shifting more fulfillment back into stores will allow it to use existing labor and inventory more flexibly, reduce delivery distances and improve order cycle times. The company has also been experimenting with smaller, regionally-dispersed delivery spokes designed to support store-based fulfillment without the cost of an Ocado hub. And that means that for Ocado the challenge now is to show that its model can prevail even when Kroger, one of its most important partners has decided that scale, at least for now, is better achieved through stores that are closer to customers and cheaper to operate than a warehouse full of robots.

Title: Netflix needs Warner Bros.‚Äôs IP and franchises to remain the default streaming service
URL: https://fortune.com/2025/12/08/netflix-warner-bros-deal-ip-franchises-default-streaming-service-ai/
Time Published: 2025-12-08T10:57:59Z
Full Content:
Good morning. There‚Äôs a lot of debate over last week‚Äôs surprise announcement that Netflix struck an $83 billion deal to acquire Warner Bros. Discovery. President Donald Trump said Sunday that their combined market share ‚Äúcould be a problem,‚Äù and the deal will face international scrutiny, too. Some takeaways so far: Warner Bros. held out for a bigger shared win. An insider told me that Warner Bros. chief David Zaslav was not eager to partner with Paramount Skydance because of financing, the price, and the fact that rookie CEO David Ellison would not only retain controlling shares but was still digesting his last win. Activate Consulting CEO Michael J. Wolf, a veteran media consultant and former president of MTV Networks, argues that this deal is a must-do for Netflix, given the rising strength of competitors like YouTube, Amazon Prime and Tubi. ‚ÄúNo doubt Netflix is the default streaming service,‚Äù Wolf told me over the weekend. ‚ÄúGoing forward, what will be required to win is more iconic IP and more global franchises that work everywhere. Warner Bros. Discovery is one of the only companies out there that will give Netflix both of these at once.‚Äù Experience matters. Content and the ability to distribute it have fueled many an entertainment merger. But history is filled with examples of those who‚Äôve generated huge value for stakeholders from such deals and many that did not. The AOL Time Warner merger proved to be an expensive cautionary tale about clashing cultures, mistimed market shifts and the perils of buying at peak bubble. (Time Warner‚Äôs Turner acquisition, on the other hand, was a home run.) I remember GE CEO Jeff Immelt telling me ‚Äúwe know this world‚Äù when merging VivendiUniversal and NBC. Turns out GE didn‚Äôt create as much value as NBC Universal‚Äôs subsequent buyer Comcast did. Netflix co-CEO Ted Sarandos is right to say that ‚Äúour mission has always been to entertain.‚Äù But even if he overcomes antitrust scrutiny, he must then win over Hollywood, investors and consumers who already balk at the idea of this new behemoth. AI is changing the game. We‚Äôve already seen how much AI is changing the entertainment game, with AI-generated actor Tilly Norwood, AI influencers, Coca-Cola commercials, and movies. Since Netflix is a longtime builder‚Äîversus a buyer‚Äîsome wonder if the streamer is interested in Warner Bros.‚Äô deep library for reasons other than simply giving consumers more stuff to consume. As Melissa Otto, head of research at S&P Global Visible Alpha, told Fortune, the future of entertainment may come down to who owns what she calls ‚Äúthe video corpus‚Äù to train and power the next generation of AI models. Contact CEO Daily via Diane Brady at diane.brady@fortune.com China‚Äôs $1 trillion trade surplus President Trump‚Äôs tariffs weren‚Äôt enough to rein in China‚Äôs exports. The country‚Äôs trade surplus blew past $1 trillion for the first time this year, with one month to spare. China‚Äôs exports to the U.S. have plummeted, falling 29% in November year-on-year, but shipments to other countries, especially in southeast Asia, have soared, making up the difference. IBM‚Äôs big AI deal IBM is reportedly in talks to buy Confluent, a company that manages real-time flow of data in big AI models, in a deal worth $11 billion. The acquisition would be IBM‚Äôs largest in recent years; the tech giant announced it was slashing thousands of jobs in November in a shift towards AI. Apple‚Äôs C-Suite shakeup Four Apple executives who report to CEO Tim Cook have stepped down in the past week, marking a major shakeup at the tech giant known for C-Suite stability that‚Äôs hampering its effort to catch up in the AI race. Germany‚Äôs largest lender will ask shareholders to approve a 47% bump for Wynaendts, which will take his pay to roughly $1.6 million. Title: I was an ambitious Amazon exec who solved my burnout without skipping a beat at work. Here's how.
URL: https://www.businessinsider.com/amazon-exec-burnout-recovery-tips-2025-12
Time Published: 2025-12-08T10:11:15Z
Full Content:
It was Friday afternoon, and I'd just hit send on my weekly report to Amazon's Retail vice presidents, detailing what the Global Merchandising team I'd created had accomplished that week. I was 38, and the role ‚Äî which oversaw standards, best practices, and technology for Amazon's 200+ site merchandisers ‚Äî was the biggest of my life by far, one I'd been thrust into just three months after my arrival in Seattle and at Amazon. I was thrilled (and a bit terrified) by the size of the opportunity, and threw myself into it. Two years in, my team had 18 sizable projects underway. We accomplished so much that documenting our progress in that weekly email took me hours ‚Äî and yet in two years, I'd rarely received so much as a "thx" in return. "At Amazon, silence from the top means you're doing a good job," a colleague reminded me, with rueful humor. She was right. But the feedback vacuum made it increasingly difficult to know if I was fulfilling my mandate. Was I moving fast enough? Still aligned with their priorities? Anxiety filled the void. I pushed myself and my team harder and took on even more. This is the first installment of Business Insider's five-part series, The Burnout Cure, which examines how people recognize burnout, confront it, and rebuild their lives on the other side. I'd once been someone with passions ‚Äî yoga, reading, arthouse movies ‚Äî but all of that had faded. When I did find time for something I enjoyed, I was distracted, worried that I'd miss an urgent email. It felt easier to stay vigilant at all times. As I stared at my email that day, I thought, None of this actually matters ‚Äî followed by the sense that I had to keep pushing forward anyway. That if I slowed down even a little, my career would collapse. Later in the parking garage, I stared numbly at the car in front of me when it hit me: Is this what burnout feels like? It was. I just hadn't realized it could happen to me. I was a naturally driven person who liked being busy; I thought burnout was for the weak. And at work, it was hard to distinguish between burning out and just keeping up. In school and at other jobs, I'd often wished that other people would think bigger and move faster; now I was surrounded by smart, fun, driven coworkers on that same wavelength. I rarely had a moment of boredom at Amazon, and I loved that. But there was a dark side. Add in scarce resources, time pressure, and our inability to say no ‚Äî to our bosses, to each other, and to ourselves ‚Äî it was a recipe for exhaustion. I'd been raised to believe I could do anything if I only tried hard enough. That worked out pretty well when it was roller skating or long division, but it started to work against me by high school. When I earned my first Cs, I saw it as a failure of willpower, not a sign that I had strengths and weaknesses like any other human. I carried that harsh self-judgment through college and grad school and into the working world. My version of self-care was drinking white wine and shopping, which often drained me further. When it dawned on me that I was burned out, I was finally able to face it. And over the next months, without ever saying a word about burnout to my boss or co-workers, I slowly pulled myself back to health. Here's what I did to get there. Shopping is fun, but what I really needed were things like sleep and food. I started reading novels before bed instead of emails. I made a point of eating lunch every day, even if it was at my desk. Occasionally, I snuck out for a short walk around the block. The views and movement left me calmer. I waited for my gentler lifestyle to blow up in my face ‚Äî all that time working at a frantic pace had convinced me that slowing down would backfire terribly. But nothing happened. It didn't seem like anyone at work even noticed, though my husband and dog did, and I even passed the occasional coworker on a walk outside the building. The stories I'd told myself about being "found out" hadn't been based in reality. I couldn't change Amazon's culture of overwork, but I could dial back some of the work I volunteered for to be helpful and prove my worth. I was someone who'd rarely turned down ad hoc committees or mentorship requests, especially when it could help elevate women. But those "after-school" assignments did little to advance my career. At performance review time, all that really mattered was what I'd done to grow the business. I decided that unless an opportunity offered a clear benefit not just to Amazon but to me ‚Äîor unless it was important to my boss, whom I trusted ‚Äî I'd turn it down. I felt like a selfish jerk at first, but once again, the sky didn't fall. People simply moved to the next candidate on the list. When I did say yes, I was more engaged and effective, sitting in hiring loops for teams I was curious about and joining occasional projects to work alongside former colleagues. Fun counts as a benefit, and pleasure helps cure burnout. A day where I laughed a lot, did work that fascinated me, or simply learned something new was a day where I got something instead of just giving. A fear of embarrassment or failure at work meant I was always ready with a fast response to any executive's question, but it also kept me from challenging myself in new ways. To keep stakes low, I began looking for modest challenges outside work that I could squeeze into small pockets of time, like learning to solve British-style crosswords or making a souffl√©. Later, I added Italian lessons, trained for a half-marathon, and joined the board of a local nonprofit serving prison inmates. My "electives," as I thought of them, became a safe place to make and learn from rookie errors, reminding me that being a beginner is exhilarating ‚Äî and that I was more than just my job. I found a therapist who specialized in cognitive behavioral therapy who showed me how to distinguish between passing thoughts and objective reality. When I thought, "If I say no to this project, someone will think I'm lazy," I learned to ask questions: Did I have evidence of that happening in the past? How about evidence of saying no and still being respected? If someone did think I was lazy, how might I cope? What would I say to a friend with the same worry? I still experienced panicky feelings, but I stopped mistaking them for facts. My comeback from burnout was imperfect and sometimes halting. At times, it scared me to feel calm and well, so I'd dive back into frantic overwork ‚Äî only to learn all over again that I wasn't more effective that way, just busier. I never worked up the courage to talk to my managers or peers about burnout, even though signs of it were everywhere. In a culture where exhaustion and overwork were worn as badges of honor, I feared that even broaching the topic would mark me as lazy or weak. As a leader, I wish I'd had the courage to push for a broader dialogue about burnout, but I also understand why it didn't feel safe. In an era of mass layoffs, I hear from tech workers who feel pushed to work harder and longer than ever before to avoid losing their jobs. They know they need to pull back, but they're afraid. I have two pieces of advice for people in that situation. The first is to recognize that pushing through burnout won't make you better at your job. The numb, frightened, sleepless version of you can't fire on all cylinders, which could put your job at risk. Prioritizing your own basic needs can be scary, but it's critical. Second, understand that small steps matter. Maybe you're not in a position to turn down extra assignments; maybe the thought of adding an Italian class or half-marathon to your life makes you laugh hysterically to keep from crying. But you can make sure to eat lunch. You can carve out a three-minute breathing space to calm your nervous system. (No one can find you in a restroom stall.) You can run modest experiments, like closing your email after a certain time in the evening, just to see how it goes. Pick something to try, and once it becomes a habit, add something else. The benefits will slowly accumulate, and you'll begin to recognize yourself again. Amazon did not provide a comment for this story. Kristi Coulter spent 12 years at Amazon and left in 2018. She's the author of "Exit Interview: The Life and Death of My Ambitious Career" and "Nothing Good Can Come From This." Jump to
